title: Thursday, 11th April 2019

Let me find some grey on the extension to say "general election risk, probably not referendum II risk"

Nomura's reliably good on this.

11:12 am
TH11:12am

(on the subject of general election risk, we must later on discuss labour's latest idea: house price targeting)

BE11:12am

GBP may rally on the article 50 extension, but it is usually how Theresa May reacts that matters more. I expect GBP vols will continue to fall as TM won’t resign with the chances of an agreement with Labour still possible, but a poor local election result (2 May) and the UK actually taking part in EU elections may be the timeline to consider for that.

1. When will Theresa May resign? It was three weeks ago in parliament at PMQs when Theresa May said: “As prime minister, I am not prepared to delay Brexit any further than 30 June.” GBP vols are collapsing in recent days as hard Brexit pricing will continue to fall after the extension is granted. But a resignation would be a game changer and we move onto figring out the next PM (probably a Brexiteer) and the timing of a possible election. The backbench 1922 meeting is today at 5pm and we’ve heard reports of TM being told in No.10 that she has lost the confidence of the party. The papers suggest that she will resign as party leader by 23 May and remain Prime Minister until a replacement is found (takes 3-6 weeks to replace her if only MPs decide and the 2nd place runner drops out). I don't’ think it will be today or tomorrow when we find out though otherwise I wouldn’t hold a GBP long. It’s more likely that she may want to try and get the deal over the line before the EU elections, if we see no progress by then she would then perhaps consider resigning. Note: The party has no mechanism to remove her until mid-December.

BE11:13am

2. Bring back the WA to parliament? There is an idea being floated in the Mail and Sun that the Withdrawal Agreement could be brought forward and allow MPs to amend it with free votes on Labour’s demands such as customs Union and a second referendum. Will that be enough to get it through is another matter. A free vote on a second referendum would not pass without whipping in favour of it by both sides.

§ Given all the negative noise why are you still long GBP then? IF we have a further unwind of Hard Brexit hedges this on balance should be delta positive for GBP and I don’t expect Theresa May to resign (yet). It also provides me a hedge in case the ECB are dovish today that we hold short EUR/GBP (given we are also long EUR/USD). It also has been a good morning of UK data with the GDP figures, the labour data remains solid and a long extension may put the BOE back into a better place of talking about rates hikes to come (currently just 4bps over the next year).

11:13 am
BE11:13am

And the related chart for that:

BE11:13am

TH11:14am

hmm

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Broader sweep from Dermot at Goodbody, who doesn't update his Brexit flowchart.

BE11:15am

Ball firmly remains in the UK court

In the lead up to last night’s meeting, there was already broad agreement that the UK would be granted that extension. The only potential stumbling block to such an outcome was going to be France. In the end, President Macron did indeed play bad cop at last night’s meeting and managed to pull back the extension date to Halloween, rather than the March 31 2020 that many EU leaders were in favour of. The ball is firmly now in the court of the UK to get a Withdrawal Agreement across the line. Indeed, this has been the case since Withdrawal Agreement was first bought back to London last November. In the space of those six months, the PM has gone around in circles between the EU, her Party, her minority government, the House of Commons and now the Labour Party in search of a way through the impasse. Yet, a deal appears as elusive as ever. With a long delay now agreed, a return to this charade is in prospect.

Spectre of uncertainty to continue for the UK economy

While Theresa May stated last night that it was still possible that the UK could leave the EU on June 1 without taking part in the EU elections, that seems a faint prospect given the chasm that still exists in talks between herself and the Labour Party. Indeed, last night’s decision takes the immediate pressure away to get a deal done. In the background, many of Theresa May’s colleagues in the Conservatives will be seething as it fights a European election campaign. The nightmare on Downing St. is set to continue up until the UK’s new exit date of October 31. Meanwhile, the spectre of uncertainty will continue for the UK economy.

BE11:15am

Happy to chat. Also, there will be no extension to the end date for Extel that finishes up tomorrow ...

Pharma eh? "the chasm that still exists in talks between herself and the Labour Party" - The Prime Minister wants a deal where we are in a customs union indefinitely (unless we decide to cast NI adrift), whereas Labour wants a permanent customs union. If you squint you can tell the difference, but the real issue is that Corbyn will not help May, and is just stringing her along to prolong the chaos.

BE11:20am

As a reminder NG reports both underlying EPS (which strips out timing, major storm costs, exceptionals, etc) and headline EPS. The former number is the one to focus on and in the statement NG says that
underlying EPS is in line with its expectations.
• Underlying EPS – there is ~£100m of higher US operating costs on the gas-replacement programme, safety issues in Rhode Island and minor storm costs. These will be offset by lower interest costs from
some non-recurring items and lower RPI-linked interest charges.
• Headline EPS – two offsetting drivers here. There is a positive from US timing over-recoveries of around $290m. On a Group basis, including some negative timing in the UK, this results in a net benefit
to headline EPS of ~2p/sh. This benefit will be returned to customers in future years. Offsetting this, there are remediation costs of ~2p/sh associated with major storm costs. Similarly, these costs are
recoverable in future years. (Company statement)

BE11:20am

So what?

11:20 am
BE11:20am

So what? Overall, with underlying EPS in line with expectations, we would expect very little reaction from
the market. RBCe underlying EPS forecast for FY19E sits at 58.6p/sh and we believe company-collated
consensus is at ~58p/sh. We note that NG, following recent ramp-up in nationalisation concerns, is now
trading on what we regard as exceptionally attractive valuation metrics. US peers continue to re-rate
and are now trading on ~19x P/E. If we use this to value the US operations of NG (which we currently
value conservatively at ~17x P/E) then the UK operations are trading at a ~13% discount to RCV. We
reiterate our Outperform recommendation.

jaws BE anything in SCAPA please ?
BE11:22am

The relatively more exciting thing in utilities -- and I'm really stretching definitions here -- is Ofwat's draft PR19 on price caps.

Severn Trent PLC (SVT:LSE): Last: 1,950, down 17.5 (-0.89%), High: 1,957, Low: 1,939, Volume: 181.23k
11:22 am
Pennon Group PLC (PNN:LSE): Last: 724.20, down 12.4 (-1.68%), High: 739.40, Low: 721.60, Volume: 215.98k
United Utilities Group PLC (UU.:LSE): Last: 820.20, down 8.6 (-1.04%), High: 827.00, Low: 816.00, Volume: 348.88k
BE11:23am

Ofwat released the draft of its 2019 price review (PR19) for these three fast track companies. PR19 will set out allowed returns, service and incentive package for the period for 2020/25. According to the draft, companies would need to spend £1.2bn to reduce pollution, reduce leakage by at least 15% by 2025 and price could decrease by 5-15%
before inflation depending on the company. Bills for customers located in
North West, South West and Midlands could see their water bills fall by as
much as £70 before inflation by 2025. Pennon said South West Water will
review the draft determination proposed by regulator Ofwat and will respond by May 24th 2019. Ofwat will announce its final determination on July 18th for these fast-track companies and on December 11th for all others.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

It's in line, basically.

BE11:24am

Morgan Stanley incoming.

BE11:24am

For Severn Trent and South West (Equal-weight) the draft determination bill
profile looks broadly in line (Exhibit 1) with the company business plan requests
(c.1-2% below). This implies only minor tweaks to the revenue profile that we set
out for the next regulatory cycle (2020-25) as we detailed in our note in January,
Testing the Waters.
For United Utilities (Underweight) the draft determination bill profile level is c.4%
lower in FY21-22 but this falls to 2% below in FY23 and 1% in FY24 and FY25.
Implying that there could be more of an impact to our revenue expectations in the first couple of years of the AMP but this should normalise later. We see most dividend risk at UU, and this lower revenue could drive additional pressure in FY21-22. However, UU is also clearly working hard to take costs out and outperform, which can build more cover - although we will not get more clarity on that for a couple of years.

M&S’s response to the fragmentation and loss of market share for Clothing & Home is to try to double the market share of Food and make it a full shop, hence the Ocado JV. However this is coming at a time of increasing competition for its core offer and we see long-term pressure on LFL sales and margins. We are cutting EPS forecasts by 16% and 27% for the next two years with risks to the downside, reduce our target price to 250p and downgrade to Underperform.
■ In this report we examine the growing threat from the premium ranges at the discounters and the growing store overlap using our proprietary store location database. We estimate that the impact on LFL from Aldi and Lidl will double from 0.7% pa to 1.2% over the next 4 years and the impact from competition across the whole market could be 2-3x this level.

BE11:50am

We analyse the Ocado JV and, while M&S needs an online solution to fulfil its broader ambitions, we believe that JV margins will be low (2.1% EBIT margins in 2022E) and the economics allow for very little cannibalisation of M&S store sales. The ambition for food to become a weekly shop destination is a direct threat to Waitrose, and we assume will lead to pressure on LFL and GM over the next 2Y before JV buying gains peak.
■ Given challenges to both parts of the business, the aggressive strategy for Food may end up being correct. However evidence of success may be 2-3 years away. In the meantime forward PER’s of 12.3x and 13.9x look expensive for a company which we expect to report 5 years of declining EPS up to 2021/22, and, following the DPS cut, the yield of 4% provides little support. Our new target price is 250p (blend of 226p based on 10x 12m PER and 280p DCF). Upside risks include faster delivery of opex savings, higher UK consumption or retained FX gains in Clothing & Home.

rw42 Last time i tried online groceries they made nonsensical substitutions, and tended to provide stuff that was close to it's best-before date while when i was in a shop i'd always look for the newest stuff to put in basket. Not sure either of those have changed since!
BE11:56am

Recent updates show Ocado has largely completed its pivot to being a technology
provider and away from being a retailer. Recent results, the M&S JV and IFRS 15 update
give us more detail on what the future business will look like. The business still faces
exposure to what we see as a niche channel with challenged mass market economics,
however, in the near term, this is a challenge for its customers and not Ocado directly.
We look at the shift in Ocado’s risk. It has lowered its direct exposure to the Grocery
Home Delivery model through the M&S JV. However, it has not changed the fundamental
economics of Grocery Home Delivery, which we believe are challenged. It has simply
pushed this back as investors will now wait for Ocado’s customers to determine whether
the model works or not. Our analysis suggests not.
We look at the valuation implications of the new model. We examine the economics
of each CFC Ocado will open for its customers and how this impacts profits going forward
given substantial start-up losses under IFRS 15 before an inflexion in Solutions profits, we
believe around FY22e. We estimate a further 40 customer fulfilment centres (CFCs) are
required to justify the current share price, in addition to the 25 already agreed, as shown
below. Longer term, we believe Ocado will only succeed if it can enable its customers to
succeed too and we believe there is risk here given the challenging economics of Grocery
Home Delivery. We also look at the importance of the M&S JV both in completing its pivot
away from retail and in raising cash to fund the capital requirements of its Ocado
Solutions Platform (OSP) contracts.
Downgrade to Reduce (from Hold), TP to 900p (from 750p). Our valuation lies
between the mid- and optimistic scenario. Implicit in our valuation is an assumption
existing agreements are a success and a further 5-7 CFCs are added.
